item.title: Putin Says He Isn’t Seeking Ukraine’s ‘Capitulation’ to End War
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said he isn’t seeking Ukraine’s “capitulation” as a way to end the war, even as he reiterated his claim that the two countries are one people.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Local residents look at damaged residential buildings following aa Russian drone attack in Odesa, on June 20.

item.title: NYC's Zohran Mamdani Tries Selling Socialism to the Home of Wall Street
item.description: For the full experience visit: NYC's Zohran Mamdani Tries Selling Socialism to the Home of Wall Street
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Zorhran Mamdani during a campaign event in New York on May 4. Photographer: Andrew Lichtenstein/Corbis News/Getty Images

item.title: Spain’s Indra Downplays Franco-German Sparring Over Fighter Jet
item.description: Indra Sistemas SA’s chairman sought to assuage doubts over Europe’s next-generation fighter-jet program, after disagreements between partners Dassault Aviation SA and Airbus SE broke into the open this week.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga

media:content.media:description: A full size model of the FCAS Future Combat Air System fighter under development by Dassault Aviation, Airbus and Indra Sistemas in Paris in 2023.

item.title: UN Chief Calls for Diplomacy as Israel-Iran War Rages
item.description: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for a return to negotiations to resolve the conflict between Israel and Iran, warning that the world is “on course to potential chaos” if it expands.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle, Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Israeli first responders enter a building that was hit by an Iranian strike in Haifa on June 20.

item.title: The US Has More Copper Than China But No Way to Refine All of It
item.description: The industry will need to overcome high energy and labor costs, environmental regulations and a glut of cheap Chinese competition to make US copper smelting great again.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Vessels and residual ore at the idled Asarco smelter in Hayden, Arizona.

item.title: Chip Stocks Slide on Report of New Possible Limits on China
item.description: Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and other chipmakers slid on Friday after the Wall Street Journal reported that the Trump administration is considering further restrictions on China.
item.dc:creator: Dana Wollman, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: A robotic arm moves 300 mm silicon semiconductor wafers inside a sorting machine in a cleanroom at the Globalfoundries Inc. semiconductor fabrication plant in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday, Nov. 30, 2022. As the US has implemented unexpectedly strict rules on the transfer of semiconductor technology to China, the EU has paved the way for chipmakers to receive unprecedented state funds to build production sites as part of its EU Chips Act. Photographer: Liesa Johannssen/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Allowed to Keep Using National Guard in LA for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump can continue to use California National Guard troops to respond to protests in Los Angeles as a legal challenge over the deployment proceeds, a federal appeals court ruled.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: California National Guard in Downtown Los Angeles. Photographer: Jim Vondruska/Getty Images

item.title: UK House of Commons Approves Legalization of Assisted Dying
item.description: The UK’s House of Commons voted to legalize assisted dying on Friday, in a move that is likely to usher in a significant cultural shift over how to handle the treatment of those with terminal illnesses.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London.

item.title: Switzerland Follows European Union in Lifting Sanctions on Syria
item.description: Switzerland is lifting economic sanctions on Syria, following an European Union decision to the same end.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Syrian central bank in Damascus, Syria, on Monday, Dec. 23, 2024. The US lifted a $10 million bounty on Syria's de facto leader Ahmed Al-Sharaa after a US delegation met with him in Damascus.

item.title: European Nations Lead Push for De-Escalation in Israel-Iran War
item.description: Talks aimed at de-escalating the week-long war between Israel and Iran got under way in Geneva on Friday after US President Donald Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to intervene militarily.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada, Akayla Gardner, Samy Adghirni

item.title: Trump Hints He’ll Hold Off Iran Strike, Give Diplomacy Time
item.description: US President Donald Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to strike Iran, dialing back on recent comments that suggested military action could be imminent.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: A firefighter walks past damage at Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on June 19. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: EU Abandons Proposal to Lower Price Cap on Russian Oil to $45
item.description: The European Union shelved a plan for a stricter price cap on Russian oil exports over concerns that the US won’t back tougher sanctions due to rising crude prices.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Suzanne Lynch, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Oil pumping jacks in Russia.

item.title: UNAIDS Executive Director: ‘The HIV Response Is in Crisis’
item.description: Winnie Byanyima says her organization has lost almost 50% of its funding, a gap that is undermining global efforts to combat HIV/AIDS.
item.dc:creator: Mishal Husain

item.title: Switzerland Pumps $300 Million Into Geneva to Offset US Aid Cuts
item.description: Switzerland plans to invest more than $300 million to help international organizations in Geneva stay afloat after cuts in financing for multilateralism led by the US.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Geneva

item.title: Cuts to Fed Salaries, CFPB Funds Blocked From Trump Tax Bill
item.description: The Senate rules-keeper has decided that Republicans can’t use President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar tax bill to strip all funding from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and to cut salaries for many Federal Reserve employees.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Poland’s Tusk Calls for Partial Recount of Presidential Vote
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk has called for a partial vote recount of the country’s presidential election amid alleged irregularities.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: A polling station in Warsaw on June 1.

item.title: Nearly 1,000 Ships’ GPS Jammed Near Iran Daily, Navy Group Says
item.description: Close to 1,000 ships a day are seeing their GPS signals jammed near Iran’s coast, according to a French naval liaison group.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A crude oil tanker.

item.title: Swiss Seek European Arms Procurement Ties to Bolster Defense
item.description: The Swiss government is seeking closer collaboration with other European nations in defense procurement, following warnings by senior officials over the country’s struggling arms industry.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: A F/A-18 fighter jets is seen during tests of Swiss Air force for take-offs and landings of jets on the A1 motorway between Avenches and Payerne, western Switzerland, on June 5, 2024, with the aim of testing and expanding the ability to decentralise their air defence resources. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP) (Photo by FABRICE COFFRINI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: UK Denies Entry to South African Politician Over Extremist Views
item.description: A controversial South African politician, previously criticized by US President Donald Trump, was denied entry to the UK on the grounds that he had aired extremist views, including support for Iran-backed Hamas and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Julius Malema.

item.title: Romanian President to Designate Bolojan as Premier
item.description: Romania’s president plans to designate Liberal Party leader Ilie Bolojan as prime minister after negotiators reached an agreement to form a new government to tackle the country’s fiscal deficit. The currency rebounded.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: PARIS, FRANCE - MARCH 27: Interim President of Romania Ilie Bolojan leaves following the 'Coalition Of The Willing' summit in support of Ukraine at Elysee Palace on March 27, 2025 in Paris, France. French President Emmanuel Macron is convening a summit of EU and NATO members from 31 countries to outline additional support for Ukraine, as it continues to defend itself against Russia's full-scale invasion. A primary aim of the summit is to discuss potential peacekeeping measures, including troops on the ground from the so-called "Coalition of the Willing." The summit comes after the United States announced Tuesday that it had brokered a partial ceasefire deal between Russia and Ukraine in the Black Sea. (Photo by Tom Nicholson/Getty Images) Photographer: Tom Nicholson/Getty Images Europe

item.title: UK Launches Security Review Over Vandalized Military Jets
item.description: The UK will conduct a full review of security at its biggest airbase after a pro-Palestine activist group posted a video on X claiming to have damaged two military aircraft there.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: A grab from a video posted by Palestine Action.

item.title: Japan Surprises With Bigger Cut to Super-Long Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan is planning to cut the issuance of super-long bonds this year by more than earlier reported as it tries to restore calm to a market spooked by recent record highs in yields.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian walks past the Ministry of Finance building in Tokyo.

item.title: Niger Junta Seizes French Nuclear Giant Orano’s Uranium Mine
item.description: Niger’s military government took control of Orano SA’s uranium mine, escalating a standoff with the French nuclear-power company.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: Orano branding.

item.title: Romania Government Talks Hit Roadblock Over Fiscal Measures
item.description: Romanian leaders hit a last-minute snag in talks to form a new government as negotiators deadlocked over how to narrow the Balkan nation’s budget deficit. The currency fell.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan, mayor of Bucharest, center, following the presidential election in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. The centrist mayor of Bucharest Nicusor Dan won Romania's presidential runoff on Sunday, quashing the ambitions of a far-right Donald Trump loyalist as voters came out in force to ensure that the Black Sea nation held steady on a pro-European path.

item.title: Thai Premier Has Few Options and Fewer Allies
item.description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra lost her second-biggest coalition partner this week, leaving her with a razor-thin majority
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai PM Visits Troops as Rivals Plan Protests for Her Ouster
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra visited troops at a border post to ease public backlash over her criticism of the army in a leaked phone call, as pro-royalist groups threatened to intensify protests demanding her resignation.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra during a meeting with soldiers at an army base near Cambodia on June 20. Source: Thailand Government Spokesman Office/AP Photo

item.title: Political Woes Could Sink Thai Economy Deeper Into Malaise
item.description: Thailand’s sudden descent into a new political crisis threatens an economy that’s already on the brink of a technical recession and bracing for the impact of the global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Sanchez Puts NATO’s Trump Plan at Risk by Opposing 5% Goal
item.description: The problems piling up for Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez in Spain are threatening to spill into next week’s NATO summit, with potentially drastic consequences for the rest of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sends Warplanes Near Taiwan After US Lawmakers Visit
item.description: China sent the most warplanes toward Taiwan since October, a move that follows US lawmakers visiting a top military figure and both the UK and Japan sailing warships through the strait separating the two sides.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

item.title: Banks Face €5 Billion French Dividend Tax Bill, Senator Says
item.description: Banks in France are facing a combined tax bill of as much as €5 billion ($5.8 billion) over contentious trades allegedly designed to escape levies on dividend payments, according to a lawmaker who dubbed the process a “fraud.”
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen, Gaspard Sebag

media:content.media:description: Stock prices.
